text: February 6 2015
a reign of strange white fluid
interrupts the morning commute across
Washington State and Oregon
coming down it looked normal but when it
landed it didn't it looked like skimming
the rain leaves a strange dirty residue
in its wake you could see people driving
their cars stopped at stoplights they
had their windshield wipers going and of
course that was just smearing the white
across the glass and people looked
baffled local news outlets report
strange concurring events at first it
seems like there is a simple explanation
as this weird rain is falling on the
very same day there's massive wildfires
burning to the south you have to wonder
are these things connected but the
theory falls short when investigators
look at weather records the problem with
that idea is that the winds are blowing
in the wrong direction any ash coming up
from those wildfires is not going to be
blown into the area where we see the
rain the chemical analysis of the rain
showed a high sodium content that was
the clincher for us
after reviewing the data the scientists
decided conclusively that this
mysterious milky rain had originated
from an ancient saline lake in Southern
Oregon sodium in the rain explains the
strange milky white color waetford uses
meteorological data to work out how it
first got into storm clouds far from the
lake a number of things happened and
they converged so you had this ancient
lake bed pretty dried out because of a
prolonged drought then on the night of
February 5th a huge windstorm yet and it
had hurricane-force winds in Southern
Oregon
the hurricane whips up all the
sodium-rich dust into the sky where it
catches the prevailing winds it carried
the dust northward when it hit the rain
storm the rain brought it down and we
had milky rain Mother Nature threw a
curveball on this one
